alert.note: Alert for Kootenai; Shoshone (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 02 at 4:29PM MST until March 03 at 6:06PM MST by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Idaho... Coeur d Alene River at Cataldo affecting Kootenai and Shoshone Counties. .Heavy rain will fall on a deep primed snowpack leading to the melt increasing. Flows in rivers will increase quickly and reach critical levels. For the Coeur d`Alene River...including Cataldo...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Coeur d Alene River at Cataldo. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 43.0 feet, Minor flooding of farmland from Cataldo downstream to Harrison is likely. The campground at Cataldo will also begin to flood. Portions of Dudley Road, west of Latour Creek, will likely be underwater and impassable. If there is significant water already in the floodplain, these impacts may occur at lower stages. Old Coeur d`Alene River Road on the North Fork of the Coeur d`Alene River may begin to flood north of the Bumblebee Bridge. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 PM PST Wednesday the stage was 42.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 43.1 feet Thursday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday morning. - Flood stage is 43.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 43.0 feet on 04/16/2006. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (4 pm PST) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Coeur d Alene River Cataldo 43.0 42.7 Wed 4 am PST 43.1 42.5 41.0 &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 330 AM PST.
